specs/train/approved/general-purpose-dec.message: Do we need to provide a document to the deployer?
Seems like a good idea, done.
What's the default? Maybe we can refer to the workers option of Watcher Api, its default is equal to the number of CPUs available.

I would not let the default be determined by something external as this threadpool is supposed to be general purpose so in the future it should also be used by other parts of Watcher. I think just documenting that the user should change it and using 2 as default (same as number of concurrent audits see https://github.com/openstack/watcher/blob/master/watcher/conf/decision_engine.py#L43) will be the best option.

Is it best when the number of threads is the same as the number of nova apis? 
By default, we can set a conservative value and prompt the user how to improve efficiency.

I propose the default to be more conservative say around 4. Suppose Watcher is installed as a service alongside other components on a machine with 32 threads with will now proceed to make 32 concurrent calls to external API's, especially on smaller clouds this could cause problems. 

However, I do not know how common it is for components to be installed on 'bare metal' or if it is more typically done by running a component inside a virtual machine. In the last case I think settings the default to the number of CPUs is a very good default value.

As note in template: If you have
  nothing to say for a whole section, just write: None
It's too late for Train, as we talked yesterday, it's better to postpone to the next release.

and/or

Ugh.

I defer to convention, but will put on record my opinion that the convention is wrong. Rant follows; feel free to stop reading now.

By itself, in English, `or` implies `exclusive or`. "Would you like coffee or tea?"

Using `or` non-exclusively is a programmer thing. (It may also be a thing in the legal field, which is where that article is aimed.) But this is not code. It's English, intended for (at least some) non-programmers.

On a side note, that article just made me mad. The pompous opinions-stated-as-assertions it cites are just hyperbolic variants of "this is bad" without a shred of technical backing to their arguments. These supposed authorities should at least have the decency to phrase it as a stylistic recommendation rather than a violation of some immutable law of grammar.

And the one about "No food or drink allowed" is just plain irrelevant: negation *does* change the meaning to "none of these". (In French -- since the article brings that up as if it should have any bearing on English -- "on ne permet pas l'un ou l'autre" isn't even proper grammar. You're supposed to say, "on ne permet ni l'un ni l'autre" -- equivalent to "neither...nor".)

Are these the same hacks who decided "affect" and "effect" are now interchangeable, or words like "irregardless" exist at all?

</rant>

I've been told by a few technical writers not to use this construct so I've avoided it here ([1] is the first Google result I found to back it up). 'or' is generally sufficient. I can add 'or both', if that would help though.

[1] http://www.slaw.ca/2011/07/27/grammar-legal-writing/

+1 please avoid and/or as it is considered redundant in technical writing. The recommendation is to use 'and' if there are two functions, and 'or' if there's a choice between the functions.
Unless of course the function is actually called "and/or", then that's a naming convention.

If so there is a potential that the existing metadata update will overwrite newer data if they both contain the same keys as it is called afterwards.

This was included so we don't overwrite any existing metadata that is set, we were failing tempest tests because of the oversight. Existing metadata would fall under user set metadata, not values we are setting in our driver so the users settings remain unaffected.

releasenotes/notes/powermax-vol-metadata.message: Not sure if this is worth having a release note. What does the end user need to know with this? This seems like an internal detail.

We were asked to include it so it would help with identifying Cinder assets on the storage backend where there are large environments. It seemed like a reasonable request and having detailed volume information about what exists on the backend serves to improve user experience in my opinion.

openstack/heat-dashboard/heat-dashboard..message: Shouldn't this heat_policy.json file a copy of the policy file from the heat package? That's my understanding when reading https://docs.openstack.org/horizon/latest/contributor/topics/policy.html#introduction

Per my understanding, it is up to the project contributors for heat-dashboard to periodically sync up the policy file and keep it up-to-date. Currently, there's no mechanism for Horizon to dynamically fetch the policies via API. It was a community goal at some point. But I haven't heard anything moving toward that directly lately. Maybe Colleen or Gloria can provide some insight into that. For the time being, it is up to project contributors to keep it up-to-date.
The policy file could be adjusted by users. How would that be handled for horizon?

For a customized policy, Horizon expects the deployer/operator to replace the default one out-of-band. Horizon have no control over policy customization. This problem's been there since the inception of OpenStack. Fetch policy over API was meant to solved this problem, among others, but looks like that discussion has cooled off.

doc/source/operations/documents/v2/docum.message:
I think it actually might make sense to remove this chart-level field for v2 schemas and replace it with an ability to configure the HTTP_PROXY etc env vars, which is supported by the requests library [0], in the Armada helm chart since I can't see a reason why you'd ever need to use different proxy_servers for different charts, as it's more about the network environment in which the charts are being deployed than where each chart is being sourced from. So it seems more convenient/correct to configure it at the Armada application level.

[0]: https://2.python-requests.org//en/latest/user/advanced/#proxies
ok, it doesn't hurt to leave it in.

The above case is the reason that it was a deliberate decision not to use env vars. Also env vars interact with all requests, not just retrieving charts so managing that no_proxy list becomes even more complicated.

I think this would still be useful as an override, even if Armada respected the proxy env variables. I could definitely conceive of a case where all charts are internal (not requiring proxy), with one or two exceptions that do need to be retrieved from the Internet. Messing with `http_proxy` and `no_proxy` after the fact might become a pain and would require Armada reconfiguration.
we'd probably want to pipe it through the promenade genesis document as well so that the armada cli that runs during genesis can see it.

deliverables/train/tripleo-heat-template.message: Does something like "Remove fluentd composable service" mean this should be a 12.0.0?

That's not really accurate application of semantic versioning.

These are full releases every time they are done, not beta releases that happen throughout a release cycle. So whether there is one major version bump or five during a given development cycle, it doesn't matter. The version number should be based on the changes included in the given release to accurately communicate the level of changes a consumer of the deliverable should expect.
It didn't last long for this comment to pop up again...
no because this the version bump occurs for the cycle. We don't bump two versions in a single release.

Well, that's kind of the problem, isn't it? We need to enforce proper use of semver, but this project doesn't follow it. Hence we end up having the same discussion every time.

Anyway, fair enough. Just expect the next person to raise the same points again in the future.

I really hate having the exact same conversations every release cycle.  Yes I understand where you're coming from but we don't actually do proper semver for these types of components because you won't be going from 11.1 to 11.2 in anything except in current upstream development.  The actual path for end users would be the latest 10.x to the latest 11.x.  We only create these numbers because of the artificial milestones and not because of actual need to bump these.  Also removal of services don't necessarily constitute a breaking change in deployment projects requiring a true major version bunp.
112f485c7fe1cc64445d3c09b2e9655026697225 removing panko, should that warrant a bump to 12.0?

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/helm/ceilome.message:
This strikes me as strange that this needs to be encoded for the keystone service region name but not the ceilometer one above. Seem like the result of this function should provide a consistent format. 

Or is the chart handling 'region_name_for_services' and 'region_name_for_shared_services' differently and that requires the encoding?

> This strikes me as strange that this needs to be encoded for the
 > keystone service region name but not the ceilometer one above. Seem
 > like the result of this function should provide a consistent
 > format.
 > 
 > Or is the chart handling 'region_name_for_services' and
 > 'region_name_for_shared_services' differently and that requires the
 > encoding?

openstack._get_service_region_name() could either get region_name from sysinv DB or have hardcoded defaults. The region_name retrieved from sysinv database is in unicode format which leads to yaml that Armada doesn't like. base._region_name() already encodes it into utf8, but the service_config.region_name in _get_service_region_name() doesn't encode it before return. The defaults are fine since they are in python strings.

I'll move the fix from here into openstack._get_service_region_name().

There two options were introduced by us in ceilometer and not needed anymore since we are using upstream ceilometer.
We should remove these overrides.
"region_name_for_services" was added by us too so we can remove the whole function "_get_conf_ceilometer_default_overrides()"

> There two options were introduced by us in ceilometer and not
 > needed anymore since we are using upstream ceilometer.
 > We should remove these overrides.

So we can remove the whole if self._region_config() block, right?

Even the block is removed, I think we still need to fix the encoding in openstack._get_service_region_name() since it's still used here for default _overrides.
Looks like you need to remove this line.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Could you please add a commit message to this patch?
this patch just add some test about update share type.it is clear in the title.i think it is OK.

NetApp is the only vendor running the functional tests for upstream patches. It's important for us to have this tests running in our environment, but we are still using Zuul v2 and it cannot interpret the depends on containing the patch link, it only works with the patch change id. Could you please change this depends on pointing to this [1] change id?
[1] I4c7bdd601d48b40c01639b5089d4bff259a7b3af
the Depends-on url is same as commit id.i think this is OK.

I think you misunderstood what Carlos is trying to convey... 
Using both URL and Change-ID will work with Zuul/Upstream CI when using the "Depends-On" syntax. 

However, third party CI systems (like NetApp CI, which Carlos maintains) may not understand how to parse the review URL - it is a relatively new feature in Zuul; and third party CIs may not be running that version. So, he's recommending that you change the Depends-On to:

  Depends-On: I4c7bdd601d48b40c01639b5089d4bff259a7b3af
ok, I see what you mean.thanks.

specs/queens/cleanup-openstack-user-conf.message: I think some form of a migration tool will be needed. Without it, existing deployments would likely be hung out to dry.

You are right.

It would be better. I don't know yet how we can do it, but we should do it indeed.

In this case we'd be increasing the variables. The user config file is a direct input into inventory which is loaded as a meta host entry and is being done to maximize performance. http://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/dev_guide/developing_inventory.html#tuning-the-external-inventory-script

Moving all of the content in the user config into group vars and/or extra variables may have an adverse effect on performance as the user config content would no longer be part of the inventory. Before we get too far into this effort we should probably conduct a bit of of a study on this to ensure we're actually moving in the right direction. 

All that said, I'm greatly in favor of simplifying the user config and eliminating things where we can and if this work results in a performance impact but is easier for everyone that comes into the project (new and old) then +2.

I think this spec should provide for some sort of a migration utility so existing deployers whom have been accustom to the user config for many cycles are not left out in the cold or required to tinker with new structures when they upgrade.

a simplification of the networking ("provider_networks") would be great however care will need to be taken to ensure whatever we move to is 100% compatible with what we have today. Secondly, we should not break away from any known structures or network wiring in a single cycle.

It's well known that group vars using the same variable name across multiple groups can be trampled on in unexpected ways when a host is a member of many groups. As such I'm a little leary of this change when it comes to networking and would rather see this included as an extra variable if we're looking to take it out of the inventory.

Sorry for misleading, my mistake. I forgot some important things.

The size return from ndctl already subtract the alignsize. It's to say, when create a 4096MB namespace (with 2MB alignment), we will get 4094MB from ndctl. It's not relavant to label. It's because 'devdax' mode require a portion of the namespace capacity to be reserved for metadata. see https://github.com/pmem/ndctl/issues/79.

The namespace label area is a small persistent partition of capacity available on some NVDIMM devices. The label area is used to resolve aliasing between pmem and blk capacity by delineating namespace boundaries. The label size is used by QEMU to create a label area in vpmem I think. For now, we don't support label size configuration in Nova.
see https://pmem.io/ndctl/ndctl-write-labels.html

In a word, it's no need to subtract the alignsize again. I tested the new code without subtracting, it works well.

The problem is not lower(), it's this bit in the task code:

  # KVM is not a hypervisor, so when using a virt_type of "kvm" the
  # hypervisor_type will still be "QEMU".
  if hypervisor_type.lower() != obj_fields.HVType.QEMU:
      return

This happens before we actually check the value of the workaround config option, which is what this test is trying to test. Because we used to test with the "kvm" hypervisor, which is 1. not real 2. not what the code checks for, this test was always a false positive because it was passing the hypervisor check before ever getting to checking the value of the workaround config option.

releasenotes/notes/numa-aware-live-migra.message:
It should be:

    .. note::

      Even in a cell fully upgraded to Train, RPC pinning via
      ``CONF.upgrade_levels.compute`` can cause live migration of instances
      with a NUMA topology to revert to the legacy naive behavior.
      For more details refer to the Upgrade section.

or

    .. note:: Even in a cell fully upgraded to Train, RPC pinning via
              ``CONF.upgrade_levels.compute`` can cause live migration of
              instances with a NUMA topology to revert to the legacy naive
              behavior. For more details refer to the Upgrade section.
and attempted on an alternate destination if the request is setup to have alternates.

less than 5.3 or a release older than "train".

--

Note that you can set specific versions or release aliases:

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/configuration/config.html#upgrade_levels.compute
"option value" sounds weird, no? Otherwise done.
Yeah, use the upgrade_levels/compute instead of "rpc" because that's what people care about and will recognize. The generic non-service-scoped "RPC" above is ambiguous.

You can get Dan's opinion but I wouldn't even include this in here. The upgrade statement is already confusing and this just adds more confusion. Let's just be clear that the computes must be upgraded to Train and the compute upgrade level can't be pinned lower than train/5.3.

Should we try to add a summary statement? Something like, "In other words, NUMA-aware live migration with the libvirt driver is not supported until (1) all compute and conductor services are upgraded to Train code and (2) the ``[upgrade_levels]/compute`` RPC API pin is removed (or set to "auto") and services are restarted.

--

Finally, this is a question for Dan, but conductor caches the min compute service version check value, so based on that summary above, is it worthwhile saying that conductor needs to be restarted to flush that cache after all computes are upgraded, unpinnned and restarted? Meaning you can't restart conductor before the computes and expect things to work b/c conductor would have a stale cache.

 > The upgrade statement is already confusing and this just adds more
 > confusion. Let's just be clear that the computes must be upgraded

if vpmem_info is '', we will get [''] from vpmems_info.split(','), it's not we want.
we should do some check, like I can input "hw:pmem=,,,", we should strip all the empty one.
Or we can let placement tell the user "we don't have this resource class"?

These should probably also be whitespace-trimmed. normalize_name will translate whitespace characters to underscores, which will lead to somewhat confusing failures. It's the admin's fault, yes, but in this case it's easy to accommodate.

Since Alex, stephen also give some comments about this, I would like do some check here, and do nothing to handle the original input, just raise a exception to inform admin to correct the flavor config. And also add a unittest for this case.

This is overly restrictive. Labels should be allowed to have underscores as well.

But I don't think you should be doing validation on this side -- just let Placement do it.

The only thing you should be doing is trimming whitespace.
Done

This will also eliminate internal spaces, which is probably not a good thing. Just use

 label.strip()

nit: I'm still not sure if this is good enough as far as normalization goes. I know we have a call to the 'normalize_name' function in the caller for this but I'd much rather explicitly reject requests that included invalid characters rather than munge them like this. I guess if others think it's okay though, I can live with it

Right, the reason I wanted to strip (surrounding) whitespace is because

 'hw:pmem': 'one, two, three'

should clearly be interpreted as

 ['one', 'two', 'three']

and not

 ['one', ' two', ' three']

but anything else should be 1) scrubbed by normalize_name and 2) allowed to fail in placement if it's bogus.

I suppose a comment to that effect wouldn't go astray.
